page.title: 12ULLAPOOL 1905- JOHAN MACLEOD
page.content: No automatic washing machines in those days!These were hard-working times. Two or three families gathered heavy bed covers and blankets and went to the river.Men carried the cooper-made, white,wooden,handled-tubs to the river and built a stone fireplace.A fire of sticks and peats was lit under a big, river-water filled,iron pot to boil the water.This water,two blankets, washing powder and soft,green soap were put into each tub and children trampled them, bare-footed, until all the dirt was out.They rinsed them down by the banks of the Ullapool River. To wring the water out of them,two people,one at each end,folded the blanket and a third held a big stick in the centre while the ends of the blanket were twisted round it.The blankets were then spread out on the grass,in the sun, to dry.
